[http://www.bltc.com/ BLTC Research] }} '''David Pearce''' is co-founder of [[Humanity+]], formerly the World Transhumanist Association, and a prominent figure within the [[transhumanism]] movement.{{cite journal| last=Bostrom | first=Nick | authorlink = Nick Bostrom |title = A history of transhumanist thought|journal = [[Journal of Evolution and Technology]] |date = April 2005 | volume=14| issue=1| url = http://www.nickbostrom.com/papers/history.pdf|at=15–16|format=PDF}}Brey, Philip; Søraker, Johnny Hartz (2009). "Philosophy of Computing and Information Technology", in Anthonie Meijers (ed.). ''Philosophy of Technology and Engineering Sciences''. Elsevier, [http://books.google.com/books?id=prvCTW4V7jEC&pg=PA1389 1389]. Based in [[Brighton]], England, Pearce maintains a series of websites devoted to transhumanist topics and what he calls the "hedonistic imperative", a moral obligation to work towards the abolition of suffering in all [[Sentience|sentient]] life.[http://humanityplus.org/philosophy/transhumanist-faq/#answer_46 "What currents are there within transhumanism?"], Transhumanist FAQ 3.0, Humanity+Hauskeller, Michael (January 2010). [http://jetpress.org/v21/hauskeller.htm "Nietzsche, the Overhuman and the Posthuman: A Reply to Stefan Sorgner"]. ''Journal of Evolution and Technology''. 21(1), 5–8. His book-length internet manifesto, ''The Hedonistic Imperative'' (1995), outlines how [[pharmacology]], [[genetic engineering]], [[nanotechnology]] and [[neurosurgery]] could [[technological convergence|converge]] to eliminate all forms of unpleasant experience from human and non-human life, replacing suffering with "gradients of bliss".[http://www.nickbostrom.com/papers/history.pdf Bostrom (2005)], 15.Pearce, David (2012). "The Biointelligence Explosion", in Amnon H. Eden, et al. (eds.). ''Singularity Hypotheses: A Scientific and Philosophical Assessment''. Berlin: Springer-Verlag, 199–236. Pearce calls this the "abolitionist project". A [[Veganism|vegan]], Pearce argues that humans have a responsibility not only to avoid [[cruelty to animals]] within human society but also to redesign the global ecosystem so that animals do not suffer [[wild animal suffering|in the wild]].Thweatt-Bates (2016), 100–101.Pearce, David (2009). [http://www.hedweb.com/abolitionist-project/reprogramming-predators.html "Reprogramming Predators"], hedweb.com. ==Hedonistic transhumanism== In 1995 Pearce set up BLTC Research, a network of websites publishing texts about transhumanism and related topics in [[pharmacology]] and [[biopsychiatry]].[http://www.bltc.com/ "Mission Statement"] and [http://www.bltc.com/library/library.htm BLTC Research library], BLTC Research.{{cite book|last=DeMars|first=William Emile|title=NGOs and Transnational Networks: Wild Cards in World Politics|publisher=Pluto Press|year=2005|at=171|isbn=074531905X}}{{cite book|last=Cass|first=Hyla|title=Natural Highs: Supplements, Nutrition, and Mind-body Techniques to Help You Feel Good All the Time|publisher=Penguin|year=2002|at=323|isbn=1583331336}} (BLTC initially stood for [[Better Living Through Chemistry]].)Pearce, David (2014). [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OGeBLcMHsn0 "Better Living Through Chemistry"], YouTube (directed by Adam Ford). He published ''The Hedonistic Imperative'' that year, arguing that "[o]ur post-human successors will rewrite the vertebrate genome, redesign the global ecosystem, and abolish suffering throughout the living world."{{cite book|author=Pearce, David|title=The Hedonistic Imperative|url=http://www.hedweb.com/hedab.htm|date=1995|publisher=hedweb.com}}[http://thefutureandyou.libsyn.com/august_27_2008_episode Interview with David Pearce], interviewed by Stephen Euin Cobb, ''The Future and You'', thefutureandyou.libsyn.com, 27 August 2008, from 00:08:00.Adams, Nathan A. IV (2004). "An Unnatural Assault on Natural Law" in Colson, Charles W. and Nigel M. de S. Cameron (eds.). ''Human Dignity in the Biotech Century: A Christian Vision for Public Policy''. Downers Grove, IL: InterVarsity, 167. ISBN 0830827838 Pearce's ideas inspired an abolitionist school of transhumanism, or "hedonistic transhumanism", based on his idea of "paradise engineering" and his argument that the abolition of suffering—which he calls the "abolitionist project"—is a moral imperative.Thweatt-Bates, Jeanine (2016). ''Cyborg Selves: A Theological Anthropology of the Posthuman''. London: Routledge, 50–51 (first published 2012).[[James Hughes (sociologist)|Hughes, James J.]] (2007). [http://ieet.org/archive/20070326-Hughes-ASU-H+Religion.pdf "The Compatibility of Religious and Transhumanist Views of Metaphysics, Suffering, Virtue and Transcendence in an Enhanced Future"], Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies, 20.[http://www.nickbostrom.com/papers/history.pdf Bostrom (2005)], 16. He defends a version of [[negative utilitarianism]]: {{Transhumanism}}
Ethical negative-utilitarianism ... attaches value in a distinctively ''moral'' sense of the term only to actions which tend to minimise or eliminate suffering. ... It stems from a deep sense of compassion at the sheer scale and intensity of suffering in the world. No amount of happiness or fun enjoyed by some organisms can notionally justify the indescribable horrors of Auschwitz. Nor can it outweigh the sporadic frightfulness of pain and despair that occurs every second of every day.Pearce, David (1995). [http://www.hedweb.com/negutil.htm "Negative Utilitarianism: Why Be Negative?"] ''The Hedonistic Imperative'', hedweb.com, ch. 2.
Outlining how drugs and technologies, including [[Brain stimulation reward|intracranial self-stimulation]] ("[[Wirehead (science fiction)|wireheading]]"), [[designer drug]]s and [[genetic engineering]], could end suffering for all sentient life, Pearce believes that "over the next thousand years or so, the biological substrates of suffering will be eradicated completely."Pearce, David (1995). [http://www.hedweb.com/hedethic/hedonist.htm "Introduction"], ''The Hedonistic Imperative'', hedweb.com. Mental suffering will be a relic of the past, just as physical suffering during surgery was eliminated by [[anaesthesia]].{{cite news|author=Power, Katherine|title=The End of Suffering |work=Philosophy Now |year=2006|url=http://philosophynow.org/issues/56/The_End_of_Suffering}}Pearce, David (2007). [http://lifeboat.com/ex/utopian.surgery "Utopian Surgery: Early Arguments Against Anesthesia in Surgery, Dentistry, and Childbirth"]. Lifeboat Foundation. The function of pain will be provided by some other signal, without the unpleasant experience. Using paradise engineering, human beings will be "animated by gradients of genetically preprogrammed bliss orders of magnitude richer than anything physiologically accessible today."Pearce, David (21 June 2012). [http://ieet.org/index.php/IEET/more/pearce20120621 "Is Humanity Accelerating Towards Apocalypse? Or Utopia?"], Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies. The increasing number of vegans and vegetarians in the transhumanism movement has been attributed in part to Pearce's influence.{{cite book|last=Fairlie|first=Simon|title=Meat: A Benign Extravagance|publisher=Chelsea Green Publishing|year=2010|at=230–231|isbn=1603583254}} A vegan himself, he has argued in favour of a "cross-species global analogue of the welfare state",{{cite news|author=Kent, James|title=The Genomic Bodhisattva |work=H+ Magazine |date=16 September 2009 |url=http://hplusmagazine.com/2009/09/16/genomic-bodhisattva/}} suggesting that humanity might eventually "reprogram predators" to limit [[predation]], reducing the suffering of prey animals.{{cite news|last1=Verchot|first1=Manon|title=Meet the people who want to turn predators into vegans|url=http://www.treehugger.com/natural-sciences/meet-the-people-who-want-to-turn-predators-into-vegans.html|publisher=TreeHugger|date=30 September 2014}} Fertility regulation could maintain herbivore populations at sustainable levels, "a more civilised and compassionate policy option than famine, predation and disease."{{cite news|last1=Dvorsky|first1=George|title=The Radical Plan To Phase Out Earth's Predatory Species|url=http://io9.com/the-radical-plan-to-eliminate-earths-predatory-species-1613342963|publisher=io9|date=30 July 2014}} ==Humanity+== In 1998 Pearce co-founded the World Transhumanist Association, known from 2008 as [[Humanity+]], with [[Nick Bostrom]], now the director of the [[Future of Humanity Institute]] at the [[University of Oxford]]. Humanity+ is an international nonprofit membership organization that "advocates the ethical use of technology to expand human capacities."[http://humanityplus.org/ "What we do"] and {{cite web|title=What is transhumanism?|publisher=Transhumanist FAQ 3.0, Humanity+|url=http://humanityplus.org/philosophy/transhumanist-faq}} Pearce is a member of the board of advisors.[http://humanityplus.org/about/advisors/ "Advisors"], Humanity+. Pearce is also a fellow of the [[Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies]],{{cite web|title=David Pearce|url=http://ieet.org/index.php/ieet/bio/pearce|publisher=Institute for Ethics and Emerging Technologies}} and sits on the futurist advisory board of the [[Lifeboat Foundation]].[http://lifeboat.com/ex/boards Advisory boards], Lifeboat Foundation. Until 2013 he was on the editorial advisory board of ''[[Medical Hypotheses]]''.{{cite web|title=''Medical Hypotheses'' Editorial Advisory Board, 2013|url=http://www.journals.elsevier.com/medical-hypotheses/editorial-board/ |work=Medical Hypotheses|deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130626004654/http://www.journals.elsevier.com/medical-hypotheses/editorial-board |archivedate=26 June 2013}} He has been interviewed by ''[[Vanity Fair (magazines)|Vanity Fair]]'' (Germany) and on [[BBC Radio 4]]'s ''[[The Moral Maze]]'', among others.{{cite news|author=Niermann, Ingo|title=Mehr Rausch für alle |work=Vanity Fair |date=5 April 2007 |url=http://hedweb.com/hedethic/vanity-fair1.html}}{{cite news|title=The pursuit of happiness |publisher=''The Moral Maze''.
